description2:
Specialized qualification studies that meet the requirements set by the National Health Fund, necessary to apply for a position as a psychotherapist (in accordance with the amendment to the Mental Health Protection Act, Article 5 of the Act of August 19, 1994, which came into force on January 1, 2024) and the Act on Certain Medical Professions of August 17, 2023 (Journal of Laws 2023, item 1972) Article 87 effective from January 1, 2024, which specifies the definition of psychotherapy and requirements for psychotherapists.

The aim of the two-stage, eight-semester postgraduate studies is to prepare students for independent psychotherapy of mental disorders in children, adolescents, and adults.
description4: Upon completion of the studies, the graduate has the possibility of certification.
descriptionP1:
The program of four-year, two-stage postgraduate studies with 1200 hours covers specialized topics in psychotherapy and general issues related to human mental functioning, psychopathology and various methods of diagnosis and treatment of mental disorders, methods of empirical verification of therapeutic effectiveness, as well as ethical and legal issues in psychotherapy.

Upon completion of the studies, the graduate has the possibility of certification.

modules.title:
First level of education
(4 semesters, 600 hours, 150 hours/semester)

subtopics.title: Ethics in the work/profession of a psychotherapist
Law and regulations in the course of psychotherapy
Introduction to psychotherapy for children and adolescents, families, couples, groups, and individuals
Indications and consequences of pharmacotherapy in psychotherapy
Mechanisms of mental disorders, biological, psychological, and social factors
Mental illness vs. mental disorder. Classification of mental disorders according to ICD-10

Organic mental disorders, including symptomatic syndromes, e.g., dementia in Alzheimer's, Pick's, Creutzfeldt-Jakob, Huntington's, Parkinson's diseases or vascular dementia, delirium, amnesia, hallucinations
Mental and behavioral disorders due to psychoactive substance use, e.g., due to alcohol, sedatives and hypnotics, tobacco, psychoactive substances
Schizophrenia, schizotypal and delusional disorders, e.g., paranoid schizophrenia, catatonic schizophrenia, delusional disorders, polymorphic psychotic disorders
Mood disorders (affective), e.g., manic episode, depressive episode, bipolar affective disorder

Neurotic, stress-related and somatoform disorders, e.g., social phobia, panic disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, severe stress reaction, dissociative disorders, persistent somatoform pain disorder, hypochondriacal disorders, neurosis

Behavioral syndromes associated with physiological disturbances and physical factors, e.g., eating disorders, nonorganic sleep disorders (insomnia, sleepwalking, night terrors, nightmares), sexual disorders (sexual aversion and lack of sexual enjoyment, orgasmic dysfunction, premature ejaculation, vaginismus, dyspareunia, excessive sexual drive), mental disorders associated with the puerperium

Disorders of adult personality and behavior, e.g., specific personality disorders (paranoid, schizoid, dissocial, emotionally unstable, anxious), pathological gambling, pathological fire-setting (pyromania), pathological stealing (kleptomania), transsexualism, gender identity disorder of childhood, disorders of sexual preference, fetishism, exhibitionism, pedophilia, sadomasochism, disorders of sexual maturation, ego-dystonic sexual orientation, sexual relationship disorder

Disorders of psychological development, e.g., specific developmental disorders of speech and language, specific developmental disorders of scholastic skills, pervasive developmental disorders (autism, Asperger's syndrome)

Behavioral and emotional disorders with onset usually occurring in childhood and adolescence, e.g., hyperkinetic disorders, depressive conduct disorder, separation anxiety disorder of childhood, phobic anxiety disorder of childhood, social anxiety disorder of childhood, tic disorders

faculty: The program will be conducted by a qualified team of specialists in the fields of psychology, psychiatry, addiction therapy, and other related disciplines. The faculty will include both academic lecturers and practitioners with many years of clinical experience.

evaluation: The assessment of learning outcomes will be based on: preparation of a project work in the field of psychotherapy, completion of a clinical internship, and passing final exams.
jobOpportunities: Graduates of the 'Psychotherapy' program will be prepared to work in various therapeutic institutions, such as mental health centers, psychotherapy clinics, psychiatric hospitals, as well as in non-governmental organizations dealing with mental health. Additionally, they will be able to run their own therapeutic practice and participate in scientific research and prevention programs.
